Title: Four Thousand Weeks: Time Management for Mortals
Author: Oliver Burkeman

Title: Buddhism Plain & Simple: The Practice of Being Aware, Right Now, Every Day
Author: Steve Hagen

Title: The Namesake
Author: Jhumpa Lahiri
My Review:
I’ve been reading books recommended to me by people I love (most recently my grandpa, dad, and now my mom) in an effort to get to know them better, to understand the things they love and admire.

This book is beautiful. The narration is perfect, at no point giving the feeling of it dragging on. Similarly, the story evokes a variety of complex emotions, always managing to make you feel like these experiences are yours (or at least related to you).

This is a book I will forever defend and see myself looking back on, going back to. I’m glad my mom recommended this to me, and, each time I think of her experiences and how much they are mirrored in this book, I manage to learn more about her.

In the end, that is the purpose of this endeavor, to empathize and learn more about the people I love in my life—not as the titles they hold in my life (e.g, mom, dad, etc), but as the individual people that they are, the lives they’ve lived and experiences they’ve had. This book helped me do that.

This book is perfect, at least to me.

Title: The Diary of a Napoleonic Foot Soldier
Author: Jakob Walter

Title: Nocturno de Chile
Author: Roberto Bolaño
My Review:
Awful read for the most part. There’s some glimpses of brilliance but it’s unbearable to read most of the time. Infuriating and convoluted. I understand that the story is the rambling of a man with a fever near his death, but damn.

I’ve read stupid books that I’ve rated the same. This is not a stupid book. This is a hell of a grind with very little reward.

Title: The Left Hand of Darkness (Hainish Cycle, #4)
Author: Ursula K. Le Guin
My Review:
One of the most unique premises I’ve ever read. An interesting look from an outsider into a world without binary gender norms, war, crazy cold temperatures, and interesting political conflicts.

Not the easiest read but a book that I’ll look back at fondly.

Title: Zeno's Conscience
Author: Italo Svevo
Additional Authors: William Weaver, Claudio Carini, Beryl de Zoete, Michael Hoffman

Title: The Snakehead: An Epic Tale of the Chinatown Underworld and the American Dream
Author: Patrick Radden Keefe

Title: The Spinoza Problem
Author: Irvin D. Yalom
My Review:
6.5-7/10

In a nutshell, although the first third of the book is fully captivating from both characters, the rest of the book loses its appeal from the Spinoza side. The dialogues feel eternal and often obtuse. They fail to enact his principles and his teachings in the same effective way the first third of the book did.

The first 30 percent of the book is great. 40-70% through, the book slows down and it definitely felt like I needed to power through. The final 30% was enjoyable, but mostly from the Alfred side.

The Alfred side, although deplorable beyond explanation, is far more interesting because it’s more story and less eternal dialogue between two characters.

Interestingly enough, the epilogue, once the story ends and the author writes in a non-fictional, historical-account manner, are among the strongest parts of the book.

Overall, a good read that I would not repeat.

Title: The Annotated Turing: A Guided Tour Through Alan Turing's Historic Paper on Computability and the Turing Machine
Author: Charles Petzold

Title: Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software
Author: Charles Petzold

Title: In the Dust of This Planet (Horror of Philosophy, #1)
Author: Eugene Thacker

Title: After Finitude: An Essay on the Necessity of Contingency
Author: Quentin Meillassoux

Title: Death in the Long Grass: A Big Game Hunter's Adventures in the African Bush
Author: Peter Hathaway Capstick

Title: The Invisible Life of Addie LaRue
Author: Victoria E. Schwab

Title: If on a Winter’s Night a Traveler
Author: Italo Calvino

Title: Mexican Gothic
Author: Silvia Moreno-Garcia
My Review:
5-5.5/10

The premise is really interesting until you discover what is truly going on. Then it’s just stupid.

The writing at many points tries to be dramatic in a way that reads like a teenage novel. In general it lacks depth, both in prose and general storytelling.

A lot of things are not explained—that’s fine, usually, but here it just seems like they truly didn’t know how to and decided to just end the book while shrugging “eh who knows, right?”

Would never reread nor recommend.

Title: Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?
Author: Philip K. Dick

Title: The Little Stranger
Author: Sarah Waters
My Review:
6.5/10

The book has its highs and lows. You can review by percentage sections of the book:

0-40%: super interesting and gripping mystery. You wonder if there is some malicious entity at play (this is not a spoiler). This is the first peak.

40-60%: lowkey boring, but you could argue it sets up the final act (which is underwhelming too).

60-80%: again very interesting, the story continues and the mystery increases. Another great peak.

80-95%: the protagonist becomes unbearable but I could easily think of men IRL being like this. Regardless, the story slows down but it’s still interesting. Not really the same suspense vibe as before but instead a character drama.

95-end: underwhelming and arguably expected, as the last 30-40 pages seem to suggest.

Overall, an enjoyable read that keeps you hooked the majority of the time.

Title: On the Shortness of Life: Life Is Long if You Know How to Use It (Penguin Great Ideas)
Author: Seneca
My Review:
“It is not that we have a short space of time, but that we waste much of it.”

That’s the gist of the book, and it’s timelessly true.

Title: La casa de los espíritus
Author: Isabel Allende
My Review:
Torn between a 5.5 or a 6/10. It is clear that I didn’t enjoy it as much as others have, though.

I really enjoyed the beginning parts, especially when detailing the love of Rosa and Esteban. I also enjoyed everything relating to Las Tres Marías: Esteban’s attempts at fixing it, the conflicts, and overall stories that stemmed from that environment. I think Allende shined when creating this setting and the life within it. This includes the story of Satigny.


Apart from that, I feel like the book was mostly weak with some rare good parts. The life of many characters did not add much to the overall story, which truly seems to unfold or culminate near the end of the book.

It often felt like a chore to read and a strong attempt at replicating Garcia Marquez. Again, I may be wrong but it’s just an opinion.

In general, I would never recommend this over 100 Years of Solitude, however I recognize its value and the fact that I may have misunderstood or under appreciated it.

Title: The Elegance of the Hedgehog
Author: Muriel Barbery
My Review: It was alright? The story is good, for the most part. Often times I find that it’s a long and ongoing ramble. Maybe that does it for some people. Wouldn’t reread.

Title: El rey de hierro (Los reyes malditos, #1)
Author: Maurice Druon

Title: Cloud Atlas
Author: David Mitchell
My Review:
Not only is it a beautifully written book, a masterpiece of narration and writing styles, but it is one of the most unique premises ever. I am so happy I decided to reread this after almost half a decade. Without a doubt, this is one of the best books I have ever read. A marvel of literature.

100/10.

Title: Blood Meridian, or, the Evening Redness in the West
Author: Cormac McCarthy

Title: The Temple of Dawn (The Sea of Fertility, #3)
Author: Yukio Mishima
My Review:
The only thing that saved this book from being ranked as 1 star is the amazing start and ~80 ish first pages. After that, it’s countless chapters of yapping, weird horny moments, and down right weird parts that would simply not fly in the last 3 decades almost anywhere in the world.

It’s a shame. The first book is a masterpiece. The second one is really good. But you can see the sharp decline in this one. I’ll still finish the tetralogy at some point this year, but definitely disappointed.

SPOILER RANT BELOW
With such a strong and captivating start, why the hell would you then jump 10-15 years or so in the future, spend over 100-200 pages talking about weird sexual fantasies or events, another 50-100 pages becoming a literal textbook about themes of reincarnation, and basically ANYTHING else except advancing the narrative?

Only in the last 50 pages (of a 330-paged book) does the plot kind of pick up, we discover that the princess is in fact the reincarnation of Kiyo and Isao, and then some more years pass and we learn she dies.

There was really no mystery. Who genuinely cared for anyone in this book?

Honda becomes this unlikeable, creepy and down bad character. His wife is just as unlikeable. The princess is a side character despite SUCH a strong presence in the first 50-100 pages.

What a shame. That’s the TLDR.

Title: A Pale View of Hills
Author: Kazuo Ishiguro
My Review:
Decided to revisit what I consider to be one of my all-time faves. 6 years later, it’s still a smooth, extremely interesting, and unique read. The story just flows. And then it all clicks.

9/10. Holds up incredibly well.

Title: Edge of Empires: A History of Georgia
Author: Donald Rayfield

Title: Notes from Underground
Author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
Additional Authors: Richard Pevear, Larissa Volokhonsky, Donald Fanger

Title: La historia interminable
Author: Michael Ende
My Review:
7/10

First half of the book is a really cool and well-written meta story. IMO the strongest part of the book.

The second half is a series of tales, loosely leading somewhere, which, although interesting, could have been 100-150 pages shorter—but then you wouldn’t have 26 chapters starting with the corresponding letter from the alphabet.

My cousin said it best: it’s the sort of book you can read to your kids, where each chapter is enough of a story, for them to fall asleep.

Enjoyable.

Title: La sombra del viento
Author: Carlos Ruiz Zafón
My Review:
7/10.

I read this book the summer after I finished high school. I decided to reread it this year to see how it held up 6 years later (damn). To my surprise, I rate it the exact same.

It has an extremely strong and captivating start, muddled with spells that are uninteresting or somewhat tedious. Despite being almost 600 pages long, the final act seems very rushed. The writing at many points feels very cheesy too.

Regardless, it’s a good story. I would have trimmed maybe 100-150 pages though.

Title: Climbing the Mango Trees: A Memoir of a Childhood in India
Author: Madhur Jaffrey

Title: Things Fall Apart (The African Trilogy, #1)
Author: Chinua Achebe
My Review:
I decided to reread this with the hopes that I could appreciate it more than my high school self did. And I did! But still not enough.

The world building is great and the story itself is really interesting. However, the writing style was just not for me. A lot of times it really was a hassle to keep reading.

The ending of the book is really strong though.

Overall, 5/10, maybe a 6.

Title: Come Closer
Author: Sara Gran
My Review: Gripping and very interesting. Would recommend.

Title: Runaway Horses (The Sea of Fertility, #2)
Author: Yukio Mishima
My Review:
Runaway Horses shares the same narrative moments of brilliance as Spring Snow, with details tying both novels together in a subtle yet powerful manner.

The theme of reincarnation is further elaborated on, having been set up first in Spring Snow, yet never too over the top.

There were moments in which I found myself skimming through some pages, which I didn’t find myself doing as much in Spring Snow. The story here is also less simple, and instead deals with heavier political ideologies as well as plots relating to conspiracies and the law.

At the end of the day, it’s a matter of personal preference. I loved Spring Snow, and I enjoyed this book, although not to the same extent. Yet it builds upon its predecessor very well.

It’s interesting more because of the overarching plot rather than Isao as a character.

I’m curious to see what the third book will offer.

Title: Zero: The Biography of a Dangerous Idea
Author: Charles Seife
My Review:
In reality, this is a 5/10 but for some reason half a star still isn’t a feature in Goodreads.

To be succinct: it feels like the author needed to reach a page or word count.

In detail:
The book struggles to pick between diving deeper into mathematical intricacies or glancing over subjects rapidly. It never does either enough, and does both pretty poorly. Who is the target audience supposed to be? It’s at times too technical for someone who is not into math, yet too shallow for math folks who were looking for another GEB-type book.

There is really no cohesion other than the author loving zero (it is a pretty cool concept), and then trying to tie it down throughout history. But the flow is weak.

It drags on and on and could be much shorter. OR the author could actually dive deeper into the concepts at hand and then the page count would be justified.

In the end, it’s my fault for thinking I could find another GEB.

Title: Platero y yo
Author: Juan Ramón Jiménez
Additional Authors: Antonio Frasconi, Myra Cohn Livingston, Joseph F. Dominguez

Title: Sonata de primavera / Sonata de estío
Author: Ramón María del Valle-Inclán

Title: Sonata de primavera (Memorias del Marqués de Bradomín, #3)
Author: Ramón María del Valle-Inclán

Title: Last Summer in the City
Author: Gianfranco Calligarich
My Review:
It starts off strong and then somewhat flattens out in the middle. It can be described as a bleaker, more mature vibe to the narrator of “Catcher in the Rye” and his mentality.

The ending is powerful. Before the last 10 pages, I was ready to give it a 6.5-7/10. After I finished it though, it easily merits a 7.5-8/10.

Worth the read, in my opinion.

“I was dealt my cards and I played them.”

Title: Pachinko
Author: Min Jin Lee
My Review:
One of the best books I have ever read. The captivating storytelling across generations is unlike anything else I’ve ever seen. I cared for every single character, and every single character felt alive and unique. At no point whatsoever did I get bored of the book, or think that something could have been better.

The book captivated me, shocked me, and left me wanting to start all over again. I felt like I was about to tear up at times.

Without a doubt, this is a masterpiece and an instant classic. This book should, and will, be spoken about among other great previous literary pieces in the future.

I can’t stress how good this book is.

Title: The American West as Living Space
Author: Wallace Stegner

Title: El pozo
Author: Juan Carlos Onetti
My Review: Great writing, confusing and with some unlikeable narrator moments. I need to reread it before EOY.

Title: Never Let Me Go
Author: Kazuo Ishiguro
My Review:
I’d give it a 7/10. The concept is interesting, and most of the times the writing feels vivid. I cant seem to like Ruth, although maybe once or twice I do empathize with her. I liked Tommy and Kath’s friendship.

Overall, not a lot happens in terms of “story completion”. They just lived their life and Katy narrates it. Again, enjoyable, but not sure if I’d read it again.

Title: Shame
Author: Salman Rushdie
My Review:
It has some great parts and it has some slow parts. U fortunately, the former does not outweigh the latter.

I found myself disliking the narrator at times.

Overall, the story was interesting, but I would say that everything good about this book is done better in Midnight’s Children.

Maybe I’ll reread it in some years and find newfound joy and appreciation. Not for now though.

Title: Spring Snow (The Sea of Fertility, #1)
Author: Yukio Mishima
My Review:
Graceful, elegant, and beautiful. It covers deep themes, presents interesting characters that feel real, and provides a unique story.

The writing is perfect.

Title: Friends, Lovers, and the Big Terrible Thing
Author: Matthew  Perry

Title: The Prophet
Author: Kahlil Gibran
My Review: Nothing inherently wrong to it, just no deeper impact caused within. Some good reflections though, and pretty impressive spiritualism, philosophy, and open mindedness.

Title: The Seven Moons of Maali Almeida
Author: Shehan Karunatilaka
My Review:
I can’t comprehend how this won the Booker Prize.

The premise is unique, I will grant it that. There’s also some interesting depictions sometimes. Those are probably the only positive notes I have from this book.

Maali is unbearable and absolutely unlikeable. He is pompous, disloyal, and honestly hard to root for. He’s extremely rude to his mother, constantly cheats and lies to the person that loves him most, and keeps committing poor choices even once he’s dead.

The second person style narrative was simply not for me. That’s a personal gripe and I understand how some may like it. I found it to be tedious and not really offer anything to the narrative. The narrative itself is often either full of unnecessary details or stacked with dialogue which often can be confusing as it does not mention who said what—even more when it’s between 3+ characters.

Funny enough, even when the conversation is between 2 characters that don't include Maali, it's so hard to figure out who is who because of how generic the characters are.

There is no tension whatsoever from page 100 till the very end. None. Nothing seems to matter. The end with the section about The Light seems rushed.

More gripes: the way Stanley talks is idiotic and cartoon-like.

Narrative plot holes and story gripes:
- why does Dr Ranee want to help Maali. It makes no sense. It’s even mentioned in the ledger at the end of the book to avoid unnecessary confrontations (butchering and abbreviating)
- what even is the point of the people in white cloaks
- what is the point of that leopard near the end
- the Mahakali was so useless and under-utilized
- who is the antagonist supposed to be?

Honestly, it’s a shame because it could have been a wonderful story had it been written in another style. Kazuo Ishiguro would have killed it.

I’m glad people liked it though. I’m bummed I didn’t. I will never grasp how this won Booker 2022, as it is one of the worst books I’ve read this year.

Title: Vanderbilt: The Rise and Fall of an American Dynasty
Author: Anderson Cooper

Title: The Elegant Universe: Superstrings, Hidden Dimensions, and the Quest for the Ultimate Theory
Author: Brian Greene

Title: The Kind Worth Killing (Henry Kimball/Lily Kintner, #1)
Author: Peter  Swanson
My Review:
Such a stupid book. The writing is middle-school level. The plot is for the most part predictable. Some twists were nice at first. In general, so many words yet such little substance. I’m glad others enjoyed it. I’m glad it cost $1 off the Apple Bookstore as I had nothing else to read for my flight. A dollar lost is not so bad. I was excited for this book, oh well.

Feels like I’m reading wattpad.

Title: Persepolis 2: The Story of a Return (Persepolis, #2)
Author: Marjane Satrapi

Title: Miracle in the Andes
Author: Nando Parrado
My Review: Probably the most riveting non-fiction book I’ve ever read. If this was a fiction book, I would say the events are too unbelievable to be true. That’s how impressive, baffling, and inspiring the story is.

Title: Tough Jews: Fathers, Sons, and Gangster Dreams
Author: Rich Cohen

Title: The Magician's Nephew
Author: C.S. Lewis
My Review:
The first third of the book is amazing. I’ve always had this vivid image of the wood between the worlds. I find it fascinating and very pretty. The concept of jumping into ponds and visiting worlds is unique, and the story shines when it talks about Cairn. It’s a shame that world, nor any other pond, is ever revisited. I understand that it’s a story about Narnia, but still.

The rest of the book is alright, and the last third alludes intensely to God via Aslan—don’t know how I never saw this as a kid. Not the biggest fan but it’s alright. It just seems to take away a bit from the fantasy, but still.

Overall, some great parts but otherwise an average book. Great for kids I assume lol.

Title: The Anatomy of Story: 22 Steps to Becoming a Master Storyteller
Author: John Truby

Title: The Creative Act: A Way of Being
Author: Rick Rubin

Title: Cadáver exquisito
Author: Agustina Bazterrica
My Review:
Por comodidad, aun que leí el libro en español, escribiré la reseña en inglés.

Review:


Although the concept is very interesting, it’s quite a heavy and graphic book. I’m not the biggest fan of the writing style, and it can get confusing when there are more than 2 characters in a scene and they are all referred to by “el”. The writing is also uninspiring, but again, it’s carried by a unique premise. You can BET this will be a tv show within the next decade.

SPOILERS:
The last 100 pages of the book seem to lead to a logical conclusion, or maybe a continuation for future books. The protagonist is continuously in disagreement with society and the cannibalistic society around him, as well as the inhumane treatment of the humans that are considered, quite literally, not humans (hence inhumane).

He seems to be getting along with Jazmine, the “product” he was gifted against his will, and begins to grow appreciation and care for her. He even begins to lash out against his sister and other members of society around him that engage in these cannibalistic, inhumane behaviors.

Yet, in the last page of the book, after begging for his ex wife to come and help with the sudden issue of Jazmine’s labor (apparently his unborn son is in trouble), the wife helps Jazmine give birth to the child and then Marcos (protagonist) kills her, to which the wife exclaims “why?! We could have gotten so many more children from her?”

This is meant to serve as a twist that he never really cared for Jazmine, maybe. Or perhaps that he was in on this with his wife all throughout and this was the plan. However, this doesn’t work. Here’s why (or so I think):

- The narrator seems to be at least partially omnipresent: always knows about Marcos, his thoughts, and his surroundings (including the characters around)
- We see Marcos’ disgust at society, the inhumane treatment of the “products”, his disgust at his sister (even calling her a hypocrite)
- We see Marcos stop talking to his ex wife, distancing himself more and more from her, all while also growing closer to Jazmine
- Marcos cares for Jazmine to the point where he sings to her, wishes she could talk, communicates with her and cares for her, checking on her and hoping that people don’t find out about them (the argument could be made that he cares for her as a “pet”, which is even more shocking and horrible considering what occurs in the book)

SO, with all of this in mind, the last page’s twist just seems kind of unfounded. There is little to no basis for it, in my opinion. Maybe the narrator also gets tricked. Who knows.

Regardless, it’s a wild book and you can bet that it’ll become a tv show within the next decade, probably by HBO (if it’s in English) or by Netflix (if produced by Argentine filmmakers)

Title: The Fabric of the Cosmos: Space, Time, and the Texture of Reality
Author: Brian Greene

Title: A Visit from the Goon Squad
Author: Jennifer Egan

Title: The Seven Husbands of Evelyn Hugo
Author: Taylor Jenkins Reid

Title: Bullshit Jobs: A Theory
Author: David Graeber
My Review:
Otto’s review from around 4-5 years ago describes most of my gripes, but to further summarize:
- extremely anecdotal
- repetitive and poorly structured at times
- could have delivered a stronger message with 100-150 less pages
- some analogies are outrageous (e., serfs and peasants having better work quality / purpose than modern day workers working BS jobs…)
- refutes (or tries to refute) many counter claims by explaining logical shortcomings/fallacies (not bad at all) BUT then states things with barely any unpacking, only to say “this is perfectly logical.”

Anyway, at times interesting—especially the first 50 ish pages. After that, you've basically read the book.

I'm happy people got to enjoy it, though. I had to drag myself through the last 100 pages.

Title: Atomic Habits: An Easy & Proven Way to Build Good Habits & Break Bad Ones
Author: James Clear
My Review:
I’m usually not a fan of self-help books: the writing style, the evident truths rephrased in new ways. However, this book is different. Despite a mostly vanilla-esque writing style, it truly does help you see things in a new and helpful way. The writing doesn’t have to be beautiful or evocative because the themes and ideas it presents are.

It is digestible, thought provoking, and honestly inspiring. It makes me want to reconsider my habits and the systems I use to achieve them.

I would recommend this to basically anyone.

Title: Maluco: La novela de los descubridores
Author: Napoleón Baccino Ponce de León

Title: Pedro Páramo
Author: Juan Rulfo
My Review: Merits a revisit, or many. Incredible atmosphere and narration. Jumps across time periods and fleshed out Comala so vividly. Leaves many questions seemingly unanswered, but it doesn’t feel incomplete. It merits revisiting with a new perspective. Amazing book.

Title: Nomadland: Surviving America in the Twenty-First Century
Author: Jessica Bruder
My Review:
The book often feels directionless. It skips from story to story, time period to time period. It feels nomadic, which makes sense. It paints the struggles of the lifestyle while also describing the freedom and benefits of it. Not the biggest fan of the writing style, but I am glad the author gave us a chance to delve so deeply into this intriguing world.

I have a feeling this will be one of the rare occasions where the movie is better.

Title: Nausea
Author: Jean-Paul Sartre
My Review:
Thoughts right after finishing:

Roquentine struggles with the motion of existence. He wishes he could stop the nausea, the awareness of being. But existing, the self realization of it, happens or it doesn’t. It doesn’t come slowly, but rather appears rapidly.

The awareness of existing can be tiring, and this nausea, this desire to not think about it, is part of existing itself.

Roquentin sometimes feels like he exists passively, and when he gets the moments of self awareness he is nauseated. He struggles with a meaning? Or looks down at those that feel that one must find meaning in their own lives despite an inherently meaningless universe.

Yet near the end he manages to achieve a connection through the record he enjoys listening to. He imagines the existence of the person who wrote the record, and the lady who sings it. He imagines their hardships and the little they might have expected to receive from the record, yet the tiny pieces of happiness any amount of success might’ve brought. Even if it’s 50 dollars for the bills.

He imagines that, although his happiness for the writer and singer might mean nothing to these individuals, if Roquentine himself was in this position, he would be touched.

Existence might still be unbearable and unbeatable, but he can at least, in some way, create something that transcends it, like the record’s tune, which exists despite scratches or blemishes. The record’s tune would still exist, abstractly, with the only mean—or one of the many—of existing in our existence being via the record. Yet, if the record were to be destroyed, it would still be somewhere, on the other side.

Maybe, he thinks, by creating something—a book, as that is all he claims to be capable of—he could leave something that is beyond existence. He would not beat it, nor would creating the book help him beat the nausea, but it would leave something for later.

Perhaps as a touching end, I remember that the beginning of the book has an editor’s note meaning that, in one way or another, Roquentine succeeded.

I might have totally misunderstood the book, but I appreciate what I took from it nonetheless.

———

Other than maybe 10-20 pages that didn’t catch me entirely (around the middle) with endless descriptions (due to his Nausea), it is an absolutely wonderful book.

4.5/5

Title: The Doors of Perception & Heaven and Hell
Author: Aldous Huxley

Title: The Defining Decade: Why Your Twenties Matter—And How to Make the Most of Them Now
Author: Meg Jay
My Review:
Some really enlightening parts, muddled by pages of what feels like the author patting themselves on the back, sharing edited stories rather than the actual lessons, and some weird takes in general. A lot of bias is present in a way I’m not sure how to describe, but many other reviewers have pointed it out too.

If the book was all the thoughtful, to-the-point lessons and themes, it would be half the size, maybe less.

My point is, it reads more like a self-help book rather than the sophisticated, direct piece I was expecting. That’s on me.

Nevertheless, the few good things are great. They make you think and they stick. Make decisions for yourself and your wellbeing as if you had to decide for the entirety of the human race, for example.

Overall: good parts, but not many enough.

Title: They Both Die at the End (Death-Cast, #1)
Author: Adam Silvera

Title: The Joy of X: A Guided Tour of Math, from One to Infinity
Author: Steven H. Strogatz

Title: Gödel, Escher, Bach: An Eternal Golden Braid
Author: Douglas R. Hofstadter

Title: A Cat, a Man, and Two Women: Stories
Author: Jun'ichirō Tanizaki

Title: Persepolis: The Story of a Childhood (Persepolis, #1)
Author: Marjane Satrapi

Title: The Restaurant at the End of the Universe (The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #2)
Author: Douglas Adams

Title: The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy (The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, #1)
Author: Douglas Adams

Title: Library of Souls (Miss Peregrine's Peculiar Children, #3)
Author: Ransom Riggs

Title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (Miss Peregrine's Peculiar Children, #1)
Author: Ransom Riggs

Title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
Author: Shirley Jackson

Title: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood
Author: Quentin Tarantino
